As a reminder, Dell is also simulcasting this presentation with slides at www.dell.com/investor. Later we will conduct a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I'd like to turn the call over to Rob Williams, Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Williams you may begin.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext:
Thank you. With me today are Michael Dell; Brian Gladden our CFO; and Brad Anderson, who leads our Servers, Storage and Networking Solutions group. Brian and Brad will review our first quarter results, then Michael will follow with his perspective on our growth strategy. 
We just posted information on Q1 results and a Vlog [video log] with Brian and Brad on our IR site at dell.com. I encourage you to review these materials. Our upcoming investor relations activities include the Bernstein CEO Conference on June 3 and our Analyst Meeting here in Austin on June 23 and 24. 
Next, I'd like to remind you that all statements made during this call that relate to future results and events, including statements about Dell's future financial and operating performance, expected component pricing, global currency volatility and anticipated customer demand are forward-looking statements that are based on our current expectations. 
Actual results and events could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements because of a number of risks and uncertainties, which are discussed in our annual and quarterly SEC filings and in the cautionary statement contained in our press release and on our website. We assume no obligation to update our forward-looking statements.
Please note that on today's call, we will be referring to non-GAAP financial measures, including non-GAAP growth margin, operating expenses, operating income, net income and earnings per share. These measures are reconciled to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the slide presentation posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at dell.com and our 8-K file today, which we encourage you to review. 
Please note that unless otherwise mentioned, all growth percentages refer to year-over-year progress. Now I'll turn it over to Brian.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext:
Thanks, Rob. We had a solid first quarter in an improving global environment. Demand has picked up, especially with our commercial customers who make up approximately 78% of our revenue. We had solid unit and revenue growth in the quarter, Solutions revenue, which includes Enterprise Servers and Networking Storage and our Services business was up 38% to $4.2 billion. Aided by the acquisition of Perot Systems. We also saw a very strong demand in the emerging countries around the world.
Our entire Commercial business continues to benefit from improved demand and the hard work we've done to improve our cost structure and the critical investments we're making to build out our Enterprise business. Our nearly $50 billion Commercial business is performing well. And this validates our strategy to expand our investments in servers, storage, software and services. Given the strategic importance of our Enterprise business, we've asked Brad Anderson to share his view on the progress we're making in Enterprise Solutions, and discuss some of the underlying growth we're seeing there.
But first, let's look at the first quarter P&L and the key performance metrics, which are laid out on Charts 5 and 6 in the web deck. Revenue in the first quarter was $14.9 billion, up 21% year-over-year and flat sequentially. This is slightly better than our typical historical seasonality. On a GAAP basis, operating income was $619 million or 4.2% of revenue, and earnings per share was $0.22, which is up 47% year-over-year. On the rest of this call, I'll refer to non-GAAP financial measures.
Operating income grew 29% to $824 million or 5.5% of revenue. Sequentially, gross margins improved slightly to 17.6%, and our OpEx was 12% of revenue. We continue to focus on improving operating income, while making key investments in products, and in sales and services resources.
Net income and earnings per share were both up 20% year-over-year. Net income was $584 million, while earnings per share was $0.30 per share. Our financing and other expenses were $68 million, up versus prior quarter driven primarily by currency evaluation of certain balance sheet items due to a strengthening U.S. dollar. Our tax rate was 22.8%. That reflects the net benefit of certain effectively settled foreign tax audits. For the year, we do expect our tax rate to be in the 27% range, consistent with our previous outlook. We generated $238 million in cash flow from operations and $400 million in free cash flow in the quarter. Over the past four quarters, we've generated $4.3 billion in free cash flow.
As you know, the first quarter is typically our weakest cash flow quarter as we make year-end bonus payments during the quarter. We also used about $130 million of cash to build some strategic inventory given the current component environment. Our working capital performance continues to be solid. Our days receivable were flat with a one-day increase in inventory days, offset by a one-day improvement in days payable, keeping our cash conversion cycle at negative 36 days. We do expect our cash conversion cycle to remain consistently in the negative mid-30s throughout the year. We ended the quarter with $11.6 billion in cash and investments. During the quarter, we reinitiated our stock buyback program with a buyback of $200 million.
We've been saying that we'd like to restart the program as we've gotten more comfortable with the credit markets, our business performance and other strategic cash usage requirements. We expect to continue a modest buyback program for the rest of the year. As part of our ongoing efforts to optimize our capital structure and our U.S. liquidity, we're also monitoring the credit markets for possible favorable entry points.
Dell Financial Services generated almost $1 billion in new originations, up 11%. We saw strong leasing demand in Large Enterprise and in the U.S. in general. The loss rates for our managed portfolio for the quarter was 7.6%, which is down 130 basis points from last year, as overall portfolio quality continues to improve. 
At the beginning of the quarter, we consolidated two Commercial based conduits in accordance with recent changes in U.S. GAAP, resulting in a net increase to financing receivables and debt of $609 million and $624 million respectively, with minimal changes to retained earnings. This accounting change has no impact on our P&L or cash flow for the quarter.
Turning to our Global business unit performance. Our Commercial business grew 22% to $11.6 billion with op inc [operating income] up 25% to $894 million. We are beginning to see some leverage here, despite the fact that we're making significant strategic investments in this part of the company.
These results represent the best growth rates we've seen in Commercial in the past two years. Large Enterprise grew 25% to $4.2 billion. Op inc in this business was up 47% to $283 million and improved to 6.7% of revenue. These results were driven by very strong server revenue growth of 61% in the quarter and good OpEx leverage, which we've been counting on as the growth returns. Client demand is also very strong, with desktops and mobility growing 22% and 14% respectively.
Our Public business grew 22% to $3.9 billion, benefiting from the Perot Systems acquisition year-over-year impact. Excluding the impact of the consolidation of Perot, we saw muted demand in U.S. Federal and our EMEA business. Op inc was up 2% to $298 million or 7.7% of revenue, driven by stronger demand in state and local governments and emerging countries.
Servers were up 17% in the quarter. Based on 2009 revenue, Gartner recently ranked Dell as the number one healthcare information technology services provider in the world. And we're beginning to see more synergy wins than we projected in this area. Our Small and Medium Business revenue was up 19% to $3.5 billion. Op inc grew 36% to $313 million and 48.9% of revenue. Our Server, Storage and Client business has all delivered strong double-digit growth in the quarter for Small and Medium Business.
Our Consumer business revenue was up 16% to $3.2 billion. Op inc was $17 million as we're just beginning to see some of the cost benefits from consolidating this business with our SMB business. Our goal continues to be to improve operating margins to 1% to 2% by the end of the year. 
Regionally, we saw solid revenue growth in the Americas and APJ, which were up 23% and 33% respectively; while Europe, EMEA, grew by 6% in the quarter. Emerging countries continue to grow very quickly with our total revenue from BRIC countries up 60%, and now representing nearly 12% of our total revenue in the company.
Moving briefly to a few key product highlights. On top of the strong Enterprise growth that Brad will talk about, we saw strong return to growth in our Commercial Client business. Revenue in mobility and desktops grew 18% and 13% respectively. Mobility units were up 27%, while desktop units were up 12%. 
Turning to Enterprise, let me turn it over to Brad Anderson to discuss some of the success we are seeing in Servers, Storage and Services.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Brian. We had a strong Enterprise solutions quarter. Our combined Server, Networking Storage Services solutions grew 38% to $4.2 billion. A year ago we said we're going to shift our portfolio to higher-margin and recurring revenue and that's exactly what we're doing. 
Let me give you some specifics. In Servers, we were tying the market on Westmere and Nehalem-EX, beating several key competitors to market. We launched a full range of Westmere blade, rack and power servers. Nehalem-EX blade and rack-based servers as well as the only scalable two-socket server capable of supporting a half a terabyte of memory, which is really ideal for databases and virtualization. 
Additionally, we shift the industry's first portfolio cloud optimize servers, our PowerEdge C Series, leveraging our unique learnings from our Data Center Custom Solutions business. All these provide significant return on investments as customers consolidate, virtualize and scale their data centers.
As a result, we're seeing a surge in server upgrades at higher ASPs. Server revenue was up 39% to $1.8 billion with units up 30% and ASPs up roughly 7%. In Storage, we're focused on the full information lifecycle for data access, data management and data tiering. We expanded our intelligent data management offerings by launching the Dell DX Object Storage Solutions for healthcare and archiving. And we are expanding our partnership with EMC with the introduction of our Dell/EMC deduplication and NX Unified Storage Solutions. 
As a whole, our storage revenue was up 4% to $554 million. EqualLogic and PowerVault led our revenue growth, up 78% and 21% respectively. More importantly our Storage product mix delivered better contribution margins. On acquisitions, the integration of Exanet and KACE are going well. Exanet provides us key file storage technology for our Unified Storage platform and KACE gives us a nice, easy to use system management platform for the mid-market.
And in Networking, we launched our first set of Brocade products. And next quarter we'll add Juniper to our networking mix. Finally, our Dell Services grew 53% to $1.9 billion. The integration of Perot is progressing well. We are in target with all the key work streams, including cost and revenue synergies. As a combined organization, we're competitively strong and are beginning to win business previously entrenched with the competition. We are effectively competing for a broader array of services contracts. We have identified now more than 300 synergy sales opportunities that are now progressing through the sales process.
In addition, both discretionary and outsourcing contract flows are gaining momentum as customers continue to focus on increasing efficiencies, reducing costs and gaining access to more utility based computing technologies. 
As you can see, we're committed to the Enterprise business. We're seeing very strong acceptance for our strategy; open, capable and affordable solutions. We look forward to discussing our approach with you in much more detail in June at the Analyst Meeting. Now let me turn it back to Brian.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad. Before we hear from Michael, I'd like to provide some additional perspective on the quarter and our views on demand going forward.
As Brad described, we're experiencing very strong server growth on the heels of launching Nehalem-EX servers before our competitors. As we indicated last quarter, we're also in the early stages of a large corporate client refresh, and we believe demand will continue to be relatively strong here.
We're primarily a commercial and increasingly an enterprise company. While we suffered during the past 18 months of weak commercial demand, we stand to benefit in this cycle. Based on the first quarter reported IDC results, we also fared better in the share metrics than we have in a while. 
As we said, we saw resurgence in commercial desktop and mobility demand in the first quarter, and that should continue for the next several quarters. We look forward to the growth here as it drives scale, operating leverage and pulls through higher margin services and S&P business. Even though it may pressure gross margins for us. 
For the second quarter, we expect seasonal improvements from our state and local government, Consumer and Education businesses. But it's also important to note that the second quarter, and the first part of the third quarter are generally periods where we see slower demand from larger Commercial customers in the U.S. and especially Europe.
Net for Dell, we expect the normal seasonal pickup in the low-single digits into the next quarter. We expect some components to remain in tight supply, with limited deflation for the next couple of quarters, and global currencies to remain somewhat volatile, especially the euro. We continue to manage OpEx in a disciplined way with lower spending in G&A and our Client business, offset by key investments in our Solutions business, focused on products, IT sales and services.
We'll be disciplined here, but we are committed to making these investments, while the environment allows it. Finally, we're committed to growing operating income dollars, while maintaining disciplined execution on working capital and our cost structure. With that, let me turn it over to Michael.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian. We're really excited about the growth in our Commercial businesses right now and had strong showings across all of our Enterprise solutions businesses: Servers, Networking, Storage and Services. Our Solutions revenue is on a $17 billion run rate, delivers gross margins in the low-30s and now contributes more than 50% of the company's gross margin dollars.
In our Commercial business, Solutions revenue grew 41% from a year ago and represents 35% of the revenue. This is a five-point mix shift from a year ago and an eight-point shift from two years ago. These solutions are resonating with customers and we're winning. Enterprise is a big part of our growth strategy and we plan to fully participate year. 
While this growth is important to our long-term success, we're also the front end of a powerful refresh in the Corporate and Public Client business. We estimate that less than 5% of large Commercial customers worldwide have made the transition to Windows 7 and Office 2010. We're also seeing Server and Storage refresh rates accelerate, as customers virtualize their data centers and transition to the latest technology. Both of these trends will be powerful catalyst for Dell's growth to help fund current and future investments. With that, let me now open the operator for questions.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Christian, can we have the first question?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Brian, question for you. At the analyst day last July you talked about 7% plus operating margins in a period of strong growth, driven by the higher margin corporate revenues. And this is the first quarter that we've seen that significant mix shift away from Consumer towards SMB and Enterprise. I wonder if you can just comment on whether the operating leverage in the model was as you expected? And if that 7% operating margin target is still a good stretch goal to think about for the back half of this year, 2011?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, Katy. That's still our target and we talk about that as more of a longer-term target that we're driving towards. I think as we've talked about it, there is nice leverage in our business when we see the Commercial business demand come back, and we're seeing that. I mean, look at the results in the Commercial businesses, in LE and SMB even Public ultimately, nice leverage with the demand coming back. But we've also said that we're going to make some pretty significant investments in shifting the business and building out our Enterprise business. And I think that's a balance that we're trying to work through as we move forward. But the leverage is clearly there and we are still targeting the 7%.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: And given the strong revenue performance you had in Enterprise and SMB, should we expect the investments for growth in those areas to accelerate in the near-term?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: I think we're being disciplined, and I think if you look at how we're managing OpEx, you'll see the leverage that we're doing with the volume growth and the unit growth. But we are simultaneously, we're executing on cost reductions in the business in places like G&A, while we're investing in some of these key Enterprise areas, whether that's product and R&D or whether that's sales and service capability.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Alexander with Raymond James.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: It seems like the strong leverage in the SMB and Enterprise sectors was offset by Public sector, and I realize Perot's got a dampening effect on the margins in that business but it looks like they would've been down considerably even excluding Perot. So can you talk about that? Is that being driven by the mix shift toward emerging markets? And can you just talk about your outlook for profitability in the Public sector for the balance of the year?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, and Perot really didn't have a big -- it doesn't have a big mix down impact on the business. It's, as you saw, in the results of that business before we acquired it, I mean, it's 7% plus sort of operating income business. The pressure we've seen in Public was really the softness in the U.S. Federal business and EMEA, and I would call out specifically the U.K. Government business was pretty weak. Those are businesses that are typically pretty high Enterprise mix, and therefore, pretty high margin. So that's the short-term dynamic we're managing through in the Public business. But still like the profitability there, still like the growth prospects and well-positioned to go forward.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: So you think this is just a temporary low, Brian, and we can get back to high-single, potentially 10% type operator margins over the next 12 months?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, I think we have to watch the growth dynamics in that sector. Obviously, there are places where you see government deficits that are going to affect spending. But we still think it's a great business, and we will continue to invest there. I think there is margin upside going forward in the business.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Richard Gardner with Citigroup.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk about gross margins. I know you managed the business to the operating margin line. But I think the Street had perhaps expected a little bit more of a gross margin rebound, given the more favorable customer mix you had in the quarter. I suspect you're going to talk about things like component pricing and I don't know maybe even a mix shift to the channel. Can you talk about whether those are the right things to think about? Or was there also competitive pressure in the quarter? And is mid-17s sort of the new level to be thinking about? Or do you still think that gross margins can get back to the 18% level or better in coming quarters?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, I mean I think you got it. I mean were focused on driving operating income, dollar growth and we feel good about the progress we've made in the quarter. We did improve margin rates by about 20 basis points versus where we were in the fourth quarter. We said we were going to move it forward. We did see the favorable mix impact of the Consumer business being seasonally down. But this was -- as you look at the dynamics on the Commercial side of the business, it was offset by strong growth in the Client business within Commercial, which obviously within Commercial is at lower rates. So those dynamics more or less offset each other but we also saw negative mix from the very strong growth in APJ and some of the emerging countries. Maybe in China, obviously, contributed to that. So those are some fundamental dynamics we're facing. The reality is we're focused on continuing to drive operating margins back up and you'll see that progress.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Can you specifically discuss any impact from competitive pressures? Or any pressures that you saw during the quarter, Brian?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, look, I wouldn't call anything out. I think there's a lot of good demand out there. The markets are feeling better, and there's good competitive dynamics out there. I mean that's nothing unusual.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Toni Sacconaghi with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on the previous question, specifically on what you saw in components in the quarter. One factor that you highlighted last quarter was you had gotten caught in a series of retail commitments and then faced a big spike, unexpected spike in DRAM pricing in the middle of the quarter, which hurt you. Extensively, that didn't repeat itself and so again I'm kind of surprised that there wasn't more gross margin leverage as well. Can you talk about what happened in terms of components in the quarter, and how that may or may not have impacted margins? And then given the strategic inventory purchases, which I gather are component pre-buys, can you talk about how you think components may or may not impact you in Q2?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, Toni, I would say we talked about the challenge with the timing of retail matching our buys with pricing, and we've more or less fixed that process in the business. So to your point, that's not something that we're at all calling out in the quarter, and it's something that I think we've managed pretty well. I would say that components continue to be relatively tight. Memory has been a bit of a challenge. I think from our perspective and I think from the markets perspective, what you would hear is that, that will continue to be a challenge for the next couple of quarters. What we've done is lock-in supply to the point where we're generally feeling pretty good about our capability to meet our needs. On the supply-side, I would say that the reality is that there's going to be continued pricing pressure there. Components are not going to be seeing the typical deflation that we've seen. So we're continuing to manage through that. I think we've done a better job this quarter in terms of passing that through and pricing in the marketplace, and that's something we've just got to continue to do.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: On the demand side, can you comment on linearity in the quarter, particularly in light of heightened concerns around macro, particularly Europe? So was demand linear? Did it actually improve over the course of the quarter and so if you look at this quarter, how was linearity? And if you can comment on the first 20 days of this month, that would be appreciated as well.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, Toni, I would say pretty linear. There were puts and takes around the world but on a globe basis pretty linear demand, and as we look at second quarter, we talked about in our outlook, that we would see the typical sort of seasonality we usually see given our exposure to the education and state government. And I would say we're going to be up a couple -- two to three kind of points versus first quarter and the second quarter and everything we've seen in the quarter so far supports that.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bill Shope with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Given your investment goals and balanced against your efficiency efforts, how should we think about the OpEx ratio this year? How should it trend from the levels we saw this quarter? Should we expect to see leverage here? Or is the focus really, this year, on longer-term growth investments?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: I think you'll see -- we'll try and manage it in a bit of a balanced way. I mean we're going to make the investments there's no question. I wouldn't expect an awful lot of leverage given that dynamic and in this market, we're going to make those critical longer-term investments for the business.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: So with that said, as a follow up, you do expect leverage this year but you don't expect any OpEx ratio so explicitly you expect it to come from the gross margin line?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: I think you'll see some leverage in OpEx but as I said earlier, we're going to continue to work to improve gross margins as well. It's all about operating income dollars, Bill.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jayson Noland with Robert Baird.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: EqualLogic was strong again on the quarter. Are there any financials you can offer up?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Revenue in EqualLogic was up I think 78% year-over-year, continues to be really a great product line, lots of growth there. Brad's here maybe talk a little bit about it?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes. We had a record quarter. I mean, we continue to see good growth in all sectors. It was particularly strong in Public, in SMB worldwide. And we're seeing increasing -- where we have sold one array. We're seeing now the repurchases of expanding that from one to two to multiple set of arrays, so now we kind of got the install base. When we think about where we're at when we first bottomed, we are now with about 18,000 arrays out in the field so we've really grown that installer base.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Just as a follow-up, what type of overall storage attach rate are you seeing to your service sales?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: We're not tracking it as server attached but we're seeing two things here though. We're seeing a large number of sales into our installed base, but we're also seeing it very attractive getting us into new accounts where we previously weren't in. So it's expanding our reach into a set of customers that we weren't previously selling to, as well.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Fox with CLSA.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: The growth in the BRIC countries over the last couple of quarters has really picked up. Is there any one or two strategies that you would particularly point to that's driving it? I know you've talked about a bunch over the last year but I'd love to get some more details on that?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: We're seeing growth really across all four of the businesses, in all the BRIC countries. BRIC plus 10 was up 57%. The 10 being kind of the next generation of significant emerging countries. So the Large Enterprise business was very strong. Public was pretty strong. This would've been not the strongest quarter for the Public business in BRIC. SMB was quite strong. Consumer continues to be strong, really great growth in India and Brazil. India, up 90% and Brazil, up 81% and Russia, 79%. So we see a lot of growth here. And our strategies are really, really working across all the businesses, and there's also a lot of strength in the brand in these countries. So if you go to China, India, Brazil on the ground, Dell has a significant presence, and is really moving quickly.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: And then Brian, is there any specific currency assumptions that you can comment on that are baked into the numbers that we can benchmark as we go forward?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: We generally don't talk about currency a lot. I mean as a global company, we manage it. I would say we've been pretty open about the fact that we generally have a longer window of hedging than most of the competitors and therefore, we try and manage out the volatility over a period of a few quarters. I think we've done a nice job managing it. And obviously over time, we have to make sure that our teams can react and price appropriately given what's going on with currency over time. But we really don't like to talk about it as a major driver of the business.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ben Reitzes with Barclays Capital.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Michael, your largest competitor just announced they're buying Palm and obviously we were seeing pretty explosive success of the iPad. I was wondering if you could comment on what, just a little bit more on Dell's tablet and cell phone or smartphone strategy? And whether any moves or any recent movements with the iPad or moves by HP change your view at all? And maybe a little bit of outlook on whether you need to make an acquisition in that space?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Well, I think one of the most immediate opportunities we see was all of the users coming online is the tremendous buildout of the data centers to feed all that data. So we're very focused on our Data Center Custom Solutions business in providing the infrastructure to all of the content providers and telcos that are feeding up all that data. A lot of data would suggest that we're supplying about 19 of the 25 largest websites in the world and really continue to have a significant presence in that tier. You're also starting to see us a bit in the device side. We're very much working with Android and Windows Mobile 7, and we see those platforms as more attractive alternatives to other suggestions that you may have offered.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: And do you, just as an -- with your experience in the industry, what do you think of the tablet space in general? Do you think it's disruptive? Additive? Doesn't cannibalize? And do you think that it has any impact on your corporate business actually, eventually and not just consumer?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Well, I think it's pretty interesting. Whenever a new device comes along it's always just kind of fun to get one and play around and kind of see what's it all about. My view is that these devices are really good for content consumption, and they're not so much content creation devices, and they also appear to be devices that create a whole new usage pattern and a whole new demand for data, which is a good thing. And they don't necessarily replace any existing device per se. Could you, on occasion, use this device instead of another device, yes. But generally speaking, the tablet form factor looks to me like a whole other device, a whole and other purchase pattern.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Maynard Um with UBS.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: First, can you just help us with the pro forma gross margins between your Product and Services segment. Of the $98 million, how do you break those out between the two segments, because making some assumptions based on your previous acquisitions, it looks like you might actually be seeing some lower or pressure on your services gross margin. Can you just tell me how that splits out and if that's correct?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, there clearly is I mean if you look at the reported data around our Services business, as we look at Perot, Perot would ultimately mix down the margin rates for our Services business. But at the op inc line, it's basically about the same operating income or slightly better than the company. So as a service asset, clearly an important asset for us. But you will see some dilution in the services gross margin over time because of that.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: And then secondly, just curious about the use of cash. Does your share repurchase signal a change in kind of your M&A strategy? And can you give us maybe any thoughts into a timing of some of the potential things that you have been talking about in the past?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, I think we've been obviously fairly transparent on our strategic needs, and I think that continues to remain a priority. I think that the signal you take from the buyback would really be around our comfort that the business continues to perform well, that the credit issues that we were troubled with a year and half ago are really behind us. And then I think we've gotten comfortable with what it is we need to accomplish in that plan in terms of strategic other uses. So I think that's how I would read it again. I would say we expect to have a relatively modest repurchase plan for the rest of the year, and as we said before, I think we said it last quarter, we would expect to be somewhat balanced and like to do both of those things make strategic investments but also do buyback.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chris Whitmore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: You reiterated your Consumer margin targets for the year. What are the top one or two levers that you'll pull to get there?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Well, I think the biggest thing we've talked about is continuing to work costs in the Consumer business. And as we announced in the last quarter, we had consolidated the Consumer business with the SMB business. That creates for us some nice leverages on the cost structure, there's businesses we've just begun to sort of realize, some of those benefits and I would also say that we continue to work aggressively to reduce the COGS and the cost of our Consumer products. Those are the two biggest levers we have as we continue to grow there.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Can you quantify the expense reductions that are under your control that you've identified for a reduction?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, well I mean we talked about it last quarter. I think there's a couple of hundred million dollar opportunity we're going after in terms of the consolidation of those two businesses.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Brad or Brian, I want to understand more the gross margin dynamics in the Commercial business, just given the comments earlier about the Nehalem and Westmere boxes being sold with higher ASPs because of the denser configurations. In the quarter reported, should we think about that then as maybe the offsetting, a lower margin contribution from the Client business that ramps? And what happens longer-term if the clients starts to really see a refresh cycle pickup? Will that overcome or offset these better margins in the Server business?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Mark, I do think that's one of the short-term dynamics that we're facing into that there will be strong growth from the client side of our Commercial business and we think that's a great thing. That for us creates obviously scale. It obviously creates opportunities to attach and sell other products that are very high margin. And that's just a dynamic we're going to face into and the reality it's going to drive more operating income dollars for the company. It may create, in the Commercial business, some pressure on gross margins. And I think that's okay. I think that's for the long term -- the direction we're driving and continuing to grow our Enterprise business at 38%. I mean that's a big measure of success in terms of our transformation and I think it's important that we make progress there to.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Michael, or Brian, just given the momentum you are seeing in BRIC and APJ in particular, should we think about Dell maybe getting more acquisitive from the services perspective next to layer in to that momentum?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: We wouldn't want to signal acquisitions before they occurred, generally not a good strategy. But certainly, as Brian said, we'll continue to be acquisitive and there are certainly capabilities that we'll want to add to our portfolio.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: When I look at your Consumer gross margin or implied gross margin trends, given your filing disclosures of the last couple of quarters, it looks like it's come under quite a bit of pressure. Could you talk about your Consumer segment gross margin trends here in the context of getting back to your 7% kind of targeted overall corporate operating margin level?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, I don't think we publish or share any of the Consumer gross margin details. You would see operating income of the Consumer business. And again, I think that's been relatively consistent in the something under 1% from the last year, with the exception of the second quarter last year I think. I think the context and the framework we've created for the 7% operating income would count on the Consumer business than the 2% plus sort of range, and I think we can get there with that. So again, the Consumer business is important for us from a scale standpoint, but we think it can generate 2% plus kind of operating income.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: When you talk about the Nehalem-EX and Westmere platforms, it looks like your Server business was down slightly on a sequential basis. Your closest peer reported something of I think it was a 4% sequential growth. I guess the question would be, did you guys see any type of pause or kind of deferral in terms of spending with regards to the Nehalem-EX platforms and the Westmere platforms coming out in this last quarter?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: No, we didn't. I think typical seasonality is down quarter-over-quarter. In fact, we were essentially flat I think maybe at around to minus one here. But no, we didn't see a pause throughout that period. The Nehalem-EX -- for both Westmere and Nehalem-EX and then -- and Nehalem-EX sensors goes on four sockets. You're seeing now the start of the qualification and validation for that. So I think you're going to see continued pick up on the Nehalem-EX as now people get past their own internal qualification processes and move more into a production buying pattern.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Bailey with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Inventory was up 12% or so quarter-over-quarter on a flat sequential revenue. And I know you said you've made some strategic purchases in the quarter. Should we expect this trend to continue as we go forward? Or should inventory start to track revenue more closely?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, David, I think we feel pretty good with the level of strategic inventory we have right now. I wouldn't expect a dramatic change in that, reserve the right given the component kind of environment to maybe do something there. But I think the other dynamic that's going on obviously as we see the growth of the Retail business, as we see the ability to put more product on the water, those are things that are obviously putting pressure on the inventory. I think we managed that pretty well in a quarter, that was a minimal impact. But again, I think you can expect it to be pretty flat.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: We're trying to manage it around the eight or nine days right now.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: And then on the Services side, you said that you saw a discretionary and outsourcing contract flow start to pick up a little bit. I was wondering if you could give a bit more detail on that either by industry vertical or geography? And as you see more new contracts signed, does that put some gross margin pressure on as those contracts start up?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: To the second part, yes, I mean as you start up and see some growth come back to that part of the business, the initial economics aren't terrific necessarily as you start up those contracts. And we are seeing a good pipeline and some nice return to growth there. I think -- and healthcare is one area that I call out that we would say has been especially strong from a vertical market standpoint.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: There's a significant amount of activity among community hospitals, for example, the United States that are implementing Hospital Information Systems, and we have leading share in that sector, and we think there's going to be very robust environment for that kind of IT activity.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Shannon Cross with Cross Research.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Brian, if you could talk a little bit about cash flow from the standpoint of what you saw puts and takes. Clearly, inventory was used this quarter. But then more importantly, sort of as we go through the year, can you give us an idea of how we should think about operating cash flow sort of quarterly in things just to keep in mind from a seasonality standpoint?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, I think the first quarter as we said is generally our weakest cash flow quarter. Obviously one of the things we do is have our bonus payout that was a driver in the quarter. Working capital, we've said we expect to continue to keep that in the mid-30s, negative mid-30s. So not a dramatic move one way or another. I mean you may see a couple of days here and there but that's generally pretty solid. We've generated $4.3 billion of free cash flow for the last four quarters on a rolling basis, and something similar we would expect this year. So there may be some seasonality as it relates to linearity in our revenue growth that affects working capital. But I think about it on a rolling 12 months kind of basis, and that's the way I think about it.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: And then Michael, can you talk a bit about -- again having been through some of these refreshes before, with Win 7 I think -- I don't know I've seen 5% to 8% of PC sort of have been refreshed at this point in time. Can you talk about how you -- I know you've talked about it before, but how do you see this rolling out? More importantly, how we should think about ASPs and given what's going on at comment side and what's required for Win 7. Just anything you can give us, because again there's a lot of used equipment out there clearly that people can kind of pull it and replace it. Some kind of a different time, so anything you can give us there that would be helpful?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: I think this is a fairly unique time because the age of the install base is as great as it's ever been. And there wasn't really a catalyst or series of catalyst to upgrade and now we believe there is, and we're seeing significant projects and conviction among customers. What I'd also tell you is that there's a real shift toward more of a data center based client model in the various forms whether it's client virtualization. So there's a shift in where that spend is going to more Servers, Storage with our PowerEdge, EqualLogic platforms. So far, the dynamic that Brian described I think you're going to see that play out here a bit where we have increased operating income firm growth in the client business, but that obviously pressures gross margins somewhat. Operating income growth is kind of what we're focused on here. I do think you'll see the Server and Storage businesses continue to grow faster. Services as well.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rob Cihra with Caris & Company.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: This is maybe for a -- sort of falling on the last point, but you do talk about corporate recovery just beginning and getting better through the second half and in fact, yes, you already had I guess the third quarter of sequential improvement in corporate. I'm just curious I guess if we're rebounding from an awfully weak several quarters, why the Q2 outlook calling for seasonally slower large corporate demand. I mean is there if we were really rebounding and refreshing, wouldn't we be able to have sort of a better than seasonal corporate outlook in the second quarter?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, I think we're building off of a pretty nice rebound we saw even into the fourth quarter. We talked about a bit of a budget flush, and we saw basically almost counter seasonal growth or flat revenue into the first quarter. I think it's been a little bit better than we've expected and better than we anticipated and talked about. But I do think you will see the typical slowdown in terms of large corporate transactions during the course of the summer and especially in Europe. I mean that's just the dynamic that you face. So I just think that's reality of the market.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeff Fidacaro with Susquehanna.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Just wondering if you can give us a little bit color on the general outlook on the growth trajectory for notebooks? And any color specifically within Europe? Some of the competitors have been talking about having to possibly raise prices in that region and if I take a look at just this quarter, the implied ASP was down a bit on your notebook space.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, I think general trajectory, market has generally been obviously the growth is coming back on the Commercial side but average selling prices for us have been more stable obviously than they were last year on the notebook side, as well as desktops. When you talk about Europe, clearly when you look at currency, sort of moving through the system over a period of time depending upon sort of hedged windows and time frames, for anybody, for any of the competitors to protect margins there they're going to have U.S dollar exposure and selling into a euro market. They're going to have to raise prices ultimately so. I mean I think that's just the reality that we're going to see and over the next couple of months if you see the U.S. dollar and euro continuing the current relationship, I think that's just a reality and it probably will ultimately impact demand.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Our final question comes from the line of Lou Miscioscia with Collins Stewart.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: My question is actually on cloud computing. When I do some checks, I do hear that a lot of folks are choosing Dell Service for that. Can you mention, are you actually using racks or blade selling more for that? Is this starting to be a meaningful portion of your business? And are you specifically customizing off the normal standard sheet that you have for different customers with that?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Yes, we formed a custom data center solution group about two and a half years ago. And I think Michael alluded earlier where -- most globally, the largest data centers moving kind of this hyper scale cloud computing model is deploying on those platforms and then we're winning more than our fair share of that volume and are now kind of leading in providing those class of solutions. And that business continues to be very strong and is particularly strong this quarter. And it's kind of built -- improved quarter-over-quarter for the last several quarters. What we've done this quarter in addition to that is that there's a lot of unique learnings from that offering, and we have now taken those learnings and created a more standard line-up of product called the PowerEdge Series C to take those -- to be able to kind of transfer those learnings into a tailored offering for more of the Fortune 500 type of accounts that are looking at putting in their own private cloud. So we think that's going to be really strong lineup, and we just launched that mid-March. So we think that's some upside going forward.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: My follow-up was on desktops. Just a little surprised, obviously, to see desktops growing faster quarter-over-quarter than notebooks. Just maybe you can give us some thoughts as to what dynamics are going on underneath that?

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Well, I think that's the refresh cycle and obviously Q4 is a seasonal period where there's a lot of Consumer notebook purchases.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Thanks everyone. We'll talk to you soon and look forward to seeing you here in Austin next month.

headline: Dell Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May-20-2010
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes today's conference call. We appreciate your participation. You may now disconnect.
